tool.name: multiplescales

param.name: Neighborhood_Size
param.dialogReference: The width and length (in cell units) of the square neighborhood of cells used to calculate the value of each cell in the result raster for each metric.
param.pythonReference: The width and length (in cell units) of the square neighborhood of cells used to calculate the value of each cell in the result raster for each metric.

param.name: Metrics_Computed
param.expression: Mean Depth | Variance | Standard Deviation | Interquartile Range | Kurtosis | Terrain Ruggedness (VRM)
param.dialogReference:
Up to four different bathymetry metrics can be computed at each specified scale:

  • Mean Depth: The mean of all cell values in the focal neighborhood, where the size of the focal neighborhood is determined by scale.

  • Variance: The second central moment of the distribution of all cell values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Standard Deviation: The extent of deviation of all cell values in the focal neighborhood from the mean value. Also defined as the square root of variance.

  • Interquartile Range: Interquartile range (IQR), a measure of variability, is the difference between the 75th percentile and 25th percentile of all values in the focal neighborhood.

  • Kurtosis: A descriptor of the shape of the distribution of all values in the focal neighborhood. More precisely, Kurtosis is defined as the fourth central moment divided by the square of the variance. This tool uses Fisher's definition of Kurtosis, where 3 is subtracted from the result to give a value of 0.0 for a perfectly normal distribution. The calculations are not corrected for statistical bias.

  • Terrain Ruggedness (VRM): The variation in three-dimensional orientation of all cells in the focal neighborhood. This measure expresses the variability in slope and aspect as a single measure. See Sappington et al. (2007) for more information.

Note: At this time, interquartile range and kurtosis can only be calculated for input rasters less than 2.0 GB in size and with neighborhood sizes less than 75. These statistics will also not be calculated for cells that reside on the border of the input raster where the focal neighborhood includes cells with no data.

References:

Sappington, J.M., K.M. Longshore, and D.B. Thomson. 2007. Quantifiying Landscape Ruggedness for Animal Habitat Analysis: A case Study Using Bighorn Sheep in the Mojave Desert. Journal of Wildlife Management. 71(5): 1419 -1426.

param.name: Output_Workspace
param.dialogReference: The path to which all result rasters will be saved. A default file name specifying the corresponding metric and scale will be assigned to each result raster.
param.pythonReference: The path to which all result rasters will be saved. A default file name specifying the corresponding metric and scale will be assigned to each result raster.

tool.summary: Calculates a variety of metrics at multiple scales in a single step for quick multi-scale analysis of a bathymetric surface raster.
tool.usage:
• Provides a quick method of investigating a bathymetric dataset when interested in multiple scales of analysis.

  • Can help identify predictors of benthic zones and structures that might not be evident without multi-scale analysis.

  • Calculates six useful bathymetry metrics including mean depth, variance, standard deviation, interquartile range, kurtosis, and terrain ruggedness (VRM).

  • Saves a raster of each chosen metric at each scale of interest to the specified output workspace.

  • In this case, scale is synonymous with the size of the square neighborhood of cells used to calculate the value of each cell in the result raster for each metric. For more information, see How Focal Statistics Works.
